large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Baby Goes to Market

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary (market, count forward).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking: “What is one food people sell at the market?”
Read for enjoyment, pausing to practice operations.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize and name numerals 0–9.
Use numerals 0—5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Understand that adding or taking away one from a small group of objects changes the total quantity by one.
Count forward or backward from a given number up to 5 to solve a problem.
Identify emotions in others.
Blend two or more syllables to create words.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Understand and use a growing number of theme words.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children count the Connecting Cube “fruits” they have in their market stall as a “farmer” gives them more to sell.
Guide children to point to the Magnetic Numeral that matches the number of “fruits” they have.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What foods are in that book?
Can you pretend to be a farmer? What fruit will you gather to sell at the market?
How many pieces of fruit did you count?
What fruit can you draw? What color is it?
What materials can you use to make a piece of fruit?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of market? How many syllables are in the word market?
How can you use blocks to build a basket to hold fruit?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Baby Goes to Market

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder talk about the feelings of others and introduce vocabulary (notice, count backward).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Baby Goes to Market.
Read closely to identify and discuss characters’ emotions.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize and name numerals 0–9.
Use numerals 0–5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Count forward or backward from a given number up to 5 to solve a problem.
Identify emotions in others.
Use pre-reading skills in self-selected books.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children identify, describe, and sort facial expressions.
Guide children to count the Activity Cards in each category (happy, sad, tired) and show how many there are.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What foods do we like?Where do they come from?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you show me someone eating in this book?
How can you use your whole body to act surprised?
Can you make a market basket with five healthy foods in it?
What could you write about how you feel today?
Can you make a person who is eating healthy food?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of feelings? Can you write that letter?
Can you build a market? What foods are people selling?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Baby Goes to Market by Atinuke, illustrated by Angela Brooksbank. Text copyright © 2017 by Atinuke. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Angela Brooksbank. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Baby Goes to Market

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share an operations strategy, play an addition game, and introduce vocabulary (add, take away).
Begin story time by revisiting Baby Goes to Market and asking the guiding question, “What is one way Baby feels at the market?”
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review operations.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize and name numerals 0–9.
Use numerals 0–5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Understand that adding or taking away one from a small group of objects changes the total quantity by one.
Count forward or backward from a given number up to 5 to solve a problem.
Identify emotions in others.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Understand and use a growing number of theme words.
Use increasingly complex sentence structures.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Number Cards to create a number line.
Guide children to use the number line to solve verbal word problems about adding and taking away foods from a shopping basket.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What foods do we like?Where do they come from?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are the foods in that book similar to the foods you eat?
Pretend you are visiting a new place. How will you find new foods there?
How can you take away two fruits from that group? How many are left?
Can you write about how you find food at a market?
Can you create a food that you want to buy at the market?
What sound does the letter a make in the word add? How can you write the word add?
Baby sees many different fruits at the market. How can you use blocks to show the different fruit Baby saw?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Baby Goes to Market by Atinuke, illustrated by Angela Brooksbank. Text copyright © 2017 by Atinuke. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Angela Brooksbank. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Let’s Make Fruit Salad!

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to reflect on learning and introduce vocabulary (fruit salad, ingredients).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Let’s Make Fruit Salad! and Baby Goes to Market .
Read interactively and connect to this week’s essential question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize and name numerals 0–9.
Use numerals 0–5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Understand that adding or taking away one from a small group of objects changes the total quantity by one.
Count forward or backward from a given number up to 5 to solve a problem.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Measure, describe, and compare capacity or how much can be placed inside an object using like units and words like “empty” and “full.”

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Identify emotions in others.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Understand and use a growing number of theme words.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children make a “fruit salad” using Connecting Cubes.
Guide children to identify numerals and contribute the correct amount of “ingredients” to the “salad.”
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What food in this book do you think would be the tastiest?
Let’s pretend we are chefs with two different ideas for a dish. Let’s compare the dishes and choose one to make.
Which bunch of fruits is the biggest? How can you tell?
What healthy food do you think is the tastiest? Write about it!
Can you make a collage that shows the ingredients of your favorite dish?
Which word has more syllables, ingredients or salad? Let’s clap it out.
Think of some some other shapes you can build with the blocks. Can you compare the size of the shapes you build?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Baby Goes to Market by Atinuke, illustrated by Angela Brooksbank. Text copyright © 2017 by Atinuke. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Angela Brooksbank. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Baby Goes to Market

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to connect to social studies, play a measurement game, and introduce vocabulary (empty, full).
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,“If you went to the market, what healthy food would you buy?”
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize and name numerals 0–9.
Use numerals 0–5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Count forward or backward from a given number up to 5 to solve a problem.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Measure, describe, and compare capacity or how much can be placed inside an object using like units and words like “empty” and “full.”

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use pretend money during play, earning money for work, and using money to buy goods and services.
Identify emotions in others.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Compose a narrative.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: “Write a story about someone who buys healthy foods at a market.”
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What kind of book do you want to read next?
Imagine you are visiting a market! Pretend to buy some new foods you have never tasted before.
How can you create a new fruit that grows in bunches of three?
Can you write a story about discovering a new fruit?
Imagine what your new fruit looks like. What will you use to create it?
Create a name for your new fruit. What letter(s) does it begin with?
Pretend you are selling your new fruit. Can you work together to build a market stand to sell it?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Baby Goes to Market by Atinuke, illustrated by Angela Brooksbank. Text copyright © 2017 by Atinuke. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Angela Brooksbank. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize one-digit numerals, 0–9.
Use concrete objects and share a verbal word problem for adding up to 5 objects.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Speech is understood by both the teacher and other adults in the school.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in classroom instruction.
Blend syllables into words.
Demonstrate understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Recognize one-digit numerals, 0–9.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting 0–5 objects from a set.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Speech is understood by both the teacher and other adults in the school.
Typically use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Self-select books and other written materials to engage in prereading behaviors.
Recognize one-digit numerals, 0–9.
Use concrete objects, create pictorial models and share a verbal word problem for adding up to 5 objects.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting 0–5 objects from a set.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Demonstrate understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Speech is understood by both the teacher and other adults in the school.
Recognize one-digit numerals, 0–9.
Recognize how much can be placed within an object.
Use concrete objects, create pictorial models and share a verbal word problem for adding up to 5 objects.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting 0–5 objects from a set.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from our own.
Speech is understood by both the teacher and other adults in the school.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Recognize one-digit numerals, 0–9.
Use concrete objects, create pictorial models and share a verbal word problem for adding up to 5 objects.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting 0–5 objects from a set.
Recognize how much can be placed within an object.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Demonstrate understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
